Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Democratic Peace - An Experimental Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Countless studies have found that democracies never fight againts other democracies, but scholars continue to debate why this pattern exists. Some argue that the democratic peace is a spurious result of omitted variables such as shared interests. Others believe that democracy causes peace but disagree about the mechanisms generating this relationship. Previous attempts have faced three serious obstacles: endogeneity, collinearity, and over-aggregation. As a consequence, it has been difficult to isolate the conditions under which democracy contributes to peace and to understand the mechanisms behind its causal power.

For decades, U.S. and foreign leaders have cited the democratic peace when analysing foreign affairs and justifying democratic enlargement. This topic is even more critical today, given the tremendous pressure for democracy in the Middle East, Asia, and North Africa. By clarifying the circumstances under which democracy fosters peace, and by identifying the mechansism through which it operates, this project could help leaders forecast the effects of democratization and the likelihood of war. Moreover, by indicating which institutional features of democracy contribute to peace, the research could inform the design of new democracies. Finally, studying how democracy affects not only war but also economic and diplomatic relations will result in new and general knowledge about the sources of international cooperation.

The researchers propose to overcome these three obstacles, mentioned above, by conducting micro-level experiments. Existing theories of the democratic peace have testable but unexplored implications about the preferences and beliefs of individual citizens and elites. The researchers will conduct a series of survey experiments in which U.S. citizens, including a subset of citizens who most resemble political elites, read about foriegn policy scenarios. The aspects of the situation, including whether the potential adversary is a democracy, will be varied. The experiments will provide micro-level evidence about how democracy affects preferences about war, while avoiding problems of endogeneity and collinnearity that have hampered previous research. The researcers will also study why individuals react differently when the target is a democracy rather than an autocracy. Democracy could promote peace by changing perceptions about the threat the opponent poses, the expected cost of war, the likelihood of success, and the morality of using violence. These and other perceptions will be examined in order to shed light on the causal mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Democracies almost never fight against other democracies, but scholars and policymakers continue to debate why this pattern exists. Some argue that the so-called democratic peace is actually a result of factors other than regime type, such as trade relations or shared interests. Others believe that democracy causes peace but disagree about the mechanisms generating this relationship. Previous attempts to resolve these debates have faced serious obstacles, including reverse causation and difficulty measuring key concepts. As a consequence, it has been difficult to isolate the conditions under which democracy contributes to peace, and to understand the mechanisms behind its causal power.

 

The PIs overcame these obstacles by fielding experiments embedded in public opinion surveys in the United States. For example, in one key set of experiments, survey respondents considered foreign policy scenarios that varied randomly on several dimensions, including whether the potential adversary was a democracy. After reviewing the scenarios, participants indicated whether they would support the use of military force against the potential adversary. Participants also answered follow-up questions that revealed why individuals react differently to democracies versus autocracies.

 

The experiments revealed that individuals in the U.S. are much less supportive of military strikes against democracies than against otherwise identical autocracies. The experiments also helped explain why democracy contributes to peace. Democracy pacifies the public primarily by changing perceptions about the threat the opponent poses, and by altering how citizens think about the ethics of war. The experiments found less support for other potential causal mechanisms, including the hypothesis that democracy contributes to peace by changing perceptions about the expected costs of war or the likelihood of success.

 

This project also examined the effects of other contextual variables that are closely related to democracy, including respect for human rights. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948) stipulates that “everyone has the right to life, liberty, and security of person.” Experiments showed that U.S. citizens were much less willing to attack a country that respects such rights than an otherwise equivalent country that violates such rights, even when the dispute concerned security issues—such as nuclear proliferation—that ostensibly had nothing to do with the treatment of individuals. Experiments also revealed why respect for human rights contributes to peace. U.S. citizens are more likely to view human rights violators as threatening, and have fewer moral qualms about fighting such countries. These findings help explain the growing sphere of peace among human-rights-respecting states.

 

These and many other findings from the project should be of value for both policymakers and scholars. For decades, U.S. and foreign leaders have cited the democratic peace when analyzing foreign affairs and justifying democratic enlargement. This topic is even more critical today, given the tremendous pressure for democracy in the Middle East, Asia, and North Africa. By clarifying the circumstances under which democracy and other contextual factors (including respect for human rights) foster peace, and by identifying the mechanisms through which they operate, the findings from this project could help leaders forecast the effects of democratization and the likelihood of war. The project also produced new data and led to the development of new experimental templates that should be valuable for future scholars.
